data.title: "Split Editor" function needs a modifier or alternative function
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 7

I kind of expect that the "Split Editor" function sends the current editor to the new tab - but instead it opens two copies - similar to the 'drag down dual view' in Visual Studio 2015. 

Would it be possible to add a modifier or create an alternative function that close the original editor, which then initiate a dual editor view ?

I more often need 2 different files open in split view - rather than editing the same file two places at one.. 

changing the default behavior of Split Editor would also be nice.

data.title: Feature to assign a particular file name to appear first in a directory listing
data.body:
In NodeJS, a file named `index.js` in a directory can very often have special meaning.

But if you have a directory with a many files (or even just a few), the `index.js` can be buried in the middle of that list in the **Explorer** view because files in a directory are sorted alphabetically.

It would be useful to be able to configure a file name like `index.js` to appear at the top of a directory, that way `index.js` would be at the top and then the remaining files would be sorted alphabetically.

data.title: New feature to switch to the last focused editor tab
data.body:
Often I'm shuffling between 2 files where I'm making a change to one, then the other, back and forth. It would be nice if there were a command that would allow switching to the last focused editor tab.

I could assign that command to a keyboard shortcut and it would allow me to easily shuffle between 2 files.

This feature would still be useful even though there's the split window view, as sometimes I don't use that view because of a small screen for example.

data.title: Extensions: Command callback arguments are getting harder to deal with
Assign "hover over tool-tip" to a  keyboard combination

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: 1.11.2, Windows 7 Pro, Service PAck 1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Hover cursor over code

Requesting a feature:

The "hover over tool-tip" is very annoying. Most of the time it blocks the code I am looking at. I am aware I can disable it in settings.json file by doing "editor.hover":  false, but I need the feature sometimes.  It would be great to assign its invocation to a keyboard combination like "CTRL+SHIFT+T". This way it is always off until you need it at which time you could invoke it by hitting "CTRL+SHIFT+T" or a keyboard combination of user's choice settable in "settings.json" file.

data.title: showInputBox overwrites input with initial value when input is empty string
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 1703

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set InputBoxOptions like so:
```typescript
        const powerShellDbgScriptArgsKey = 'powerShellDebugScriptArgs';

        let options: vscode.InputBoxOptions = {
            ignoreFocusOut: true,
            placeHolder: "Enter script arguments or leave empty to pass no args",
        }

        let prevArgs = this.context.globalState.get(powerShellDbgScriptArgsKey, '');
        if (prevArgs.length > 0) {
            options.value = prevArgs;
        }

        return vscode.window.showInputBox(options).then(text => {
            if (text !== undefined) {
                this.context.globalState.update(powerShellDbgScriptArgsKey, text);
                return new Array(text);
            }

            return text;
        });
```
2. When you run this, the user should be able to press Enter on an empty input box to tell us to send no args to the script. However, since we prepopulate the input box with the previous set of arguments, they clear the input box and press Enter.  Unfortunately, that passes the previous arguments as the text instead of the empty string that was in the inputbox before they pressed Enter.

Is there a workaround I can use to get the InputBox to return an empty string when there is an initial (default) value set and the user clears that value and presses Enter?

data.title: Would love to be able to fast-project-switch
data.body:
gitkraken has a neat dropdown in the top left of their interface.  Basically enumerates all known repositories.

Would be neat if code did something similar, except for projects.  That way I don't have to do the `ctrl-shift-n` keystroke and then drill over to whatever directory I need.

data.title: Does not kill processes spawned by plugins, even after uninstall
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.11.2 (1.11.2)
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Flow running? No

        $ ps aux | grep flow
            36458   0.0  0.0  2433828    792 s002  S+    3:58PM   0:00.00 grep flow

2. `ext install vscode-flow-ide`

3. Flow running? Yes. Ok.

        $ ps aux | grep flow
        36745  77.2  5.5 27533024 930788   ??  R     4:01PM   1:10.21 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36896  75.6  2.9 27071692 486060   ??  R     4:03PM   0:23.35 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        37162  74.8  1.5 26837004 249920   ??  R     4:03PM   0:14.13 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36660  67.3 26.2 36228108 4401732   ??  R     4:00PM   2:06.29 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36508   0.0  0.2 26673176  27236   ??  Ss    3:58PM   0:02.10 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        37230   0.0  0.0  2432804    776 s002  S+    4:03PM   0:00.00 grep flow
        36514   0.0  0.0  2496456   2708   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.92 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow
        36512   0.0  0.0 26594388    224   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.00 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36511   0.0  0.0 26594388    388   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.02 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36510   0.0  0.0 26594388    420   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.02 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36509   0.0  0.0 26594388    400   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.02 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .

4. Quit VSCode. Flow running? Yes. Not ok.

        $ ps aux | grep flow
        36745  77.2  5.5 27533024 930788   ??  R     4:01PM   1:10.21 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36896  75.6  2.9 27071692 486060   ??  R     4:03PM   0:23.35 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        37162  74.8  1.5 26837004 249920   ??  R     4:03PM   0:14.13 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36660  67.3 26.2 36228108 4401732   ??  R     4:00PM   2:06.29 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36508   0.0  0.2 26673176  27236   ??  Ss    3:58PM   0:02.10 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        37230   0.0  0.0  2432804    776 s002  S+    4:03PM   0:00.00 grep flow
        36514   0.0  0.0  2496456   2708   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.92 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow
        36512   0.0  0.0 26594388    224   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.00 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36511   0.0  0.0 26594388    388   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.02 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36510   0.0  0.0 26594388    420   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.02 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36509   0.0  0.0 26594388    400   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.02 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .

5. Uninstall extension
6. Quit VSCode
7. Flow running? Yes. Not ok.

        $ ps aux | grep flow
        36745  77.2  5.5 27533024 930788   ??  R     4:01PM   1:10.21 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36896  75.6  2.9 27071692 486060   ??  R     4:03PM   0:23.35 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        37162  74.8  1.5 26837004 249920   ??  R     4:03PM   0:14.13 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36660  67.3 26.2 36228108 4401732   ??  R     4:00PM   2:06.29 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36508   0.0  0.2 26673176  27236   ??  Ss    3:58PM   0:02.10 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        37230   0.0  0.0  2432804    776 s002  S+    4:03PM   0:00.00 grep flow
        36514   0.0  0.0  2496456   2708   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.92 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow
        36512   0.0  0.0 26594388    224   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.00 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36511   0.0  0.0 26594388    388   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.02 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36510   0.0  0.0 26594388    420   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.02 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .
        36509   0.0  0.0 26594388    400   ??  S     3:58PM   0:00.02 ./node_modules/flow-bin/vendor/flow start --temp-dir /private/tmp/flow .

8. `pkill -9 -f 'flow'` peace at last

I'm not sure if this a problem with the specific extension, but VSCode should not allow processes spawned by extensions to stay running after the editor has quit. I almost completely locked up my computer trying out several Flowtype extensions, not realizing they were all spawning background tasks that didn't die.

I also now have no idea what other background processes VSCode has left open from extensions.

data.title: disabled extension causes overridding extension to not load (even after uninstall)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e

- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. install extension via vsix file
2. disable the extension (set to disabled - always from the extension UI)
3. open the extension project in workspace
4. press F5 to launch runtime instance with extension from workspace

=> the extension from the workspace is not enabled, because the installed version of the extension is disabled.

This should not be the case from my point of view. The launched extension should always be enabled.

This gets worse if you uninstall the extension (via the extension UI) while it is disabled. After uninstallting and reloading the window (or restarting code completely), the behavior stays the same. The extension in the runtime instance is disabled and there is no way to re-enable it (since there is no entry for it showing up in the extension UI).

The only solution here is to re-install the extension from a vsix file (it is still disabled after this), enable it again, then uninstall it again.

data.title: Preventing duplicate tab close when doing a middle click
data.body: Fixes https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25529
